MEDISAVE SCHEME


    Order read for Resumption of Debate on Question [30th August, 1983],

    "That this House having noted the National Health Plan - A Blue Paper by the Ministry of Health, February 1983 as contained in Paper Misc. 4 of 1983,

    (1) approves in principle the Medisave Scheme which will enable Singaporeans to set aside their own savings to meet future hospitalisation expenses; and

Column: 124



    (2) recommends that there be periodic reviews in the implementation of the Scheme and that adjustments be made when experience shows this to be desirable. ". - [Minister of Defence and Second Minister for Health].

    Question again proposed.

     Encik Othman bin Haron Eusofe (Geylang Serai): Mr Speaker, Sir, let me state at the outset that, in principle, the Medisave Scheme is worthy of support. There is no doubt that certain illness will occur no matter how much preventive care has been taken to stay fit. Singaporeans are, however, a pragmatic people and as the funds in their Medisave accounts belong to them there is an incentive for them to do their best to maintain and safeguard their health. I am happy to note that the Ministry of Health will be implementing a planned programme to educate and motivate the population to stay healthy.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like now to offer the following comments on the Medisave Scheme for the Minister's consideration.

    First, the level of Government subsidy. The Minister has stated that the Government has no choice but to gradually decrease the level of subsidy. I am concerned that the proposed reduction in subsidy will seriously affect the low wage earners. Because of their low wages, the amounts in their Medisave accounts will be small and, once used, will require a great length of time to replenish. I am glad that the Minister has categorically assured that Singaporeans will receive medical treatment regardless of their ability to pay. However, while there is the provision to allow for loan or overdraft facilities for those with inadequate Medisave accounts, there will be some who will have genuine difficulty in coping up with their own or their families' hospitalization needs even though their hospital charges are subsidized. There is really no point in allowing their loans or overdraft facilities to accumulate if there is no likelihood that they will be in a position to pay the bill. Their health will further deteriorate because of the constant worry about the loan which they have accumulated. I hope the Minister will consider carefully proposals for reduction in the subsidy. The subsidy should not be reduced to a level where the workers will

Column: 125

find it difficult to pay for their basic hospitalization needs. There must be a point where the State must bear the burden for health care without additional recovery at the point of consumption. This may mean that the subsidy may have to be even higher than the planned 50% of the Class C ward charges. At this point, the Ministry of Health must simply convince the Ministry of Finance that funds are needed to provide its hospital services. I hope the Minister will consider this carefully.

    I am also happy that the Minister has assured that those who are genuinely poor and need frequent or prolonged hospitalization can seek remission of their hospital bills. People suffering from chronic or catastrophic illness should also be covered by Government subsidies.

    Staff of Government hospitals must be sensitive and show compassion and understanding when they deal with patients whose Medisave accounts are low. They must clearly show at the ground that basic hospital care is available to all citizens regardless of the amounts in their Medisave accounts.

Employers' Medical Benefit Schemes

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I would now like to turn to the Medical and Hospitalization Benefits offered by employers to their employees. It is necessary to ensure that the introduction of the Medisave Scheme will not provide employers with the convenient excuse or opportunity to either withdraw or reduce their existing company medical and hospitalization benefits to their employees, especially now that employers need not pay more in CPF contribution to start the Medisave Scheme. Medisave should be used to supplement the existing employers' medical and hospitalization benefits scheme.

    At present, all contributions to the CPF belong to the employee, namely, it is a part of his wage which is paid to the CPF for withdrawal on retirement. The only difference is that he must now retain some funds in the Special Account after his retirement for his hospitalization needs. Any suggestion that a part of the current

Column: 126

contribution should be used for payment of the employee's medical bills first, before the company medical benefits can be utilized, will amount to the worker using his own funds first. This will be most unfair.

    I hope that for the public sector employees, the Government and the statutory boards as employers will set the example by continuing with their existing medical benefits scheme. The public sector employees can still contribute to their Medisave accounts but this should be used to supplement the present Government/Statutory Boards Medical Benefit Schemes, for example, to pay for such charges which are not covered by the current medical benefit scheme. I hope that the Minister for Health will take this up with the Minister for Finance.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I support the Motion.
2.40 p.m.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Motion, as it is worded in the Order Paper, limits discussion or debate in this House to the Medisave Scheme propounded in this so-called National Health Plan. This has been remarked upon by other Members of the House. But before I come to deal more closely with the Medisave part of this Report, may I say something on the contents of the National Health Plan report as a whole.

    The Second Minister for Health, in moving his Motion, said that a general complaint was that the report was too concise and did not have enough details. I could not agree more with this complaint, Mr Speaker, Sir. We all know that brevity is the soul of wit. But, Mr Speaker, Sir, this was not meant to be an after-dinner speech to amuse the Singapore citizens or this House. This report was intended to be a serious study and a report on our future medical plan and in that it is my respectful submission to the Minister and to the Ministry it dismally fails.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the first part of this report which deals with the National Health Plan or how health care will be delivered to our citizens abounds, if I may say so, with platitudinous statements and pious hopes. That is not what is expected

Column: 127

from a serious study put forward by a Ministry of this Government in presenting a plan to the people of Singapore. This Government prides itself, and we hear it very often, on its professionalism. Where is the professionalism in this report? If I may say so it is a very amateurish report. I understood from the Minister that it was prepared by his Ministry. I have no reason to doubt it. But one would think the report was perhaps prepared at No. 11, Napier Road rather than at the Cuppage Centre.

    May I illustrate this point that I am making about the platitudinous statements and pious hopes that this report abounds in and the complete absence of any details of what the Government has or proposes to do to deliver health care to the citizens. We have the statement that the NUS will increase its intake of medical students to see that there will be more doctors by the year 2000. The question is: will an increase of doctors, a mere increase of doctors, lead to better health care and improvement in the quality? It does not follow. The question is: how are we going to deploy the medical personnel at our disposal to provide the delivery of health care? In that, this report fails to answer. We know the example of the United States. There they abound in doctors. They have got far too many doctors, they say. Yet, has their health care improved as a result of the large number of doctors in the United States? I shall, before I sit down, make some comparison of the health care that is prevailing in these countries and you will find that the United States lags behind other European countries. And yet they have got far more doctors than these other countries. So it is these statements - the hope that if we have more doctors our health care will somehow be improved.

    The other thing is that the report does not address itself to all sections of our people. A study like this, the National Health Plan, must address itself to all sections, as I said of the Budget. You cannot just deal with one section of the population. You have got to say what you intend to do with all sections of the population, and the answer would appear to be, according to the authors of the report, "We will only deal with one particular section

Column: 128

and God take care of the rest." There is the chronically sick. There is the old age problem. There is the question of out-patient fees. It does not deal with them. It says, "That is not our business." Well, it is your business to look after the chronically sick if you are a responsible Government. It is your business, I say, to look after the aged, the aging in our midst. You do not absolve yourself of this responsibility. So, Mr Speaker, Sir, I say that this report is seriously deficient in not setting out at all concrete proposals on how the Government intends to take care of the health of the citizens in the years to come.

    May I say, Mr Speaker, Sir, that I was mentioning this report to a man who should know something about this because, after all, he was for many years in the Government service and he was an able administrator. And these were his words: "What are you going to debate about this report? There is nothing in it. You are going to waste your time talking about this report." These were his words. What plan does that report hold?

    Now, before you ask someone to draw up a report or plan, you give him the terms of reference. We did not hear from the Second Minister for Health what terms of reference were given to those who were asked to prepare this report. What was the remedy or what was the mischief, what was the problem they were asked to address themselves to and to propose the remedy for it? Was the problem the problem of decreasing, or finding a way of decreasing, the cost to the Government of delivering medical care to the citizens? Is that the problem that they were asked to consider? "See how best you can cut down Government expenditure on this health care of our people." Or was this the problem that was posed to them, "Can you put up a plan to see that all our citizens are given the best possible health care within the means available to us?" I would like to know from the Minister what were the terms of reference that were given to the people who were asked to draw up this report? I am not alone in thinking that the terms of reference that were given to those who drew up this report were what I said at first. "My dear boys, would you please see how we can reduce the cost to the

Column: 129

Government of this health care and try and present it in a palatable way?" That, I see, is also the view shared by the Association of Private Medical Practitioners. We have stated this even before we saw that letter in our newsletter, The Hammer The whole concern of this report would appear to be: "How best can we reduce the cost to the Government of this health care of our people." Mr Speaker, Sir, may I say that is entirely the wrong objective. The persons who were asked to draw up this report were put on the wrong track, on the wrong rails, and off they went like a shot on this track, and present a beautiful scheme to reduce Government expenditure on health care. So I say, Mr Speaker, Sir, they started off on the wrong foot and therefore it has gone completely off the rails from what we expected of the Government in presenting a health plan for the people.

    May I, in support of what I have said, Mr Speaker, Sir, refer - I do not want to repeat what has already been said by other Members of this House. I am aware, Mr Speaker, Sir, that you have the unenviable task of having to listen to speeches after speeches in the same vein, and so I must try and avoid that. But there is this fallacious assumption - I only say this to reiterate or underscore what has been said - the fallacious assumption that runs through the whole of this report, that somehow Singaporeans enjoy being ill, that somehow they must be penalized if they fall ill, somehow disincentives must be provided to those who fall ill. May I remind the Ministry, and I am sure they do not need reminding, that illness, accidents are not the making of the individual. You never know when you will be struck down. So I say, Mr Speaker, Sir, it is an insult to our people to say that they enjoy being ill, an assumption that if the Class C charges were somewhat reduced or even done away with, people will be queueing up every morning outside the Class C wards to gain admission. I say that is a gross insult to our people. We have only yesterday, I think, seen the results of a survey carried out by the NTUC, and what do they come up with - that our workers do not enjoy being ill. They do not, upon the least

Column: 130

excuse, enter hospitals or stay at home saying that they are ill. So why do we have to exaggerate this? Why do we have to build up this picture in order to justify something that we wish to do, and that is to cut down the cost? We keep saying demand is overtaking supply. It is not. As statistics show, the demand for hospital beds in Singapore compares very favourably with other countries. Where is the evidence of demand even now?

    Now, Mr Speaker, Sir, what does this report really set out to do? Stripped of all its flowery language, stripped of all the embroidery around it, what it does when we come to the Medisave, because this is what we have been asked to debate in this House, is to alter the method of collection of fees by the Government. That is all it does, Mr Speaker, Sir. It alters the method of collection. The Government has probably decided that at the moment it is a bit embarrassing to have to insist on deposits from patients who are unable to afford the deposits. There were two letters to the press sometime ago about accident cases where they were asked to put down some money before they could be admitted. So the Government thought this is "a source of embarrassment to us." Then there was the embarrassment of having to go after persons who did not pay their hospital charges. The Member for Rochore talked about the reason being to write off bad debts. There was that embarrassment. Now, as it stands, if a Class C patient does not pay his medical charges and is discharged, then the Government has to go after him, threaten him with proceedings and, in the last resort, if it is still determined to recover these costs, get it out of him by a court order, make the poor man bankrupt or levy execution on his chattels. That is very embarrassing, and I suppose the Government decided that it cannot really do this sort of thing, even a capitalist government, a government that believes only in profits. So it decided it would alter the method of collection, and I have a sneaking suspicion, Mr Speaker, Sir, that that was the term of reference that was given to these persons, "Can you find a way of collecting these fees without we having to require deposits, without we having to chase Class C patients who have the misfortune to be unable to pay for their

Column: 131

medical fees before being discharged from the hospital?" And so somebody in this Ministry, or was it at 11 Napier Road, said, "Hey presto, what about the CPF? We have allowed our citizens to buy houses through the CPF savings. Why don't we collect from the CPF? There you are. The money is lying there. We do not have to issue a writ. We do not have to write letters. We do not have to ask them for deposits." And so the whole thing finds expression in this wonderful report that they say they have - the National Health Plan. "Use the man's CPF savings so that we can get paid. Then we would not have to chase after him." I say, Mr Speaker, Sir, that would appear to have been the objective for this report.

    May I say to the Second Health Minister - I suppose, to the two Ministers for Health - that this should not have been called the National Health Plan Report. It should have been called more appropriately Health Fee Recovery Plan, a plan for Government to recover the fees levied by it and particularly on Class C patients. And this plan is presented - and I say this in all sincerity - to lull the citizens into accepting further higher costs to them in medical care. Because if they are allowed to pay out of CPF, and the man is told he has got to pay something more, he might say, "Well, I suppose it is all right. It is not coming out of my pocket immediately. I've still got what I've got in my pocket. It is only coming out of something there. So I suppose it's all right. I won't grumble too much." It is like signing for whatever you consume on credit cards. And the poor man does not realize that at some distant date in the future he will probably have nothing there. But it is made less painful to him. And therefore this is to lull the citizens into accepting increased charges to them in medical care and in hospital fees in particular.

    The Minister says quite happily the Government intends to maintain its subsidy. He gave some figures. He said, "Take the Class C cost to be $100." At present, Government subsidizes 90% and the patient is asked to pay only $10. Well, that does not take care of other fees. We know that there is, included in that $10, Mr Speaker, Sir, a charge for laboratory and

Column: 132

X-ray tests. But I understand, and I understood at the last Budget debate, that this $10 is charged as a flat fee, regardless of whether the poor man or woman has had any laboratory or X-ray tests. So that is dishonest. But it is not just that. It is not just $10. There is also the other fees, operation fees, radiotherapy fees. Class C patients are called upon to pay all that. Why hide all this? Let us come out with everything. Do not keep things up your sleeves.

    "Let us say", the Minister said, "the costs go up to $115." Well, I smell something there. I suppose if this is accepted, the next thing we know is that the fees for Class C will go up. He says if it goes up to $115 from $100, the Class C patient will probably be charged $10 of the increase of $15. That is two-thirds. The Government will only pay a subsidy of $5. But that reduces the subsidy immediately from 90% to 82.6%. That seems to be the whole point of this operation. How can we progressively go on reducing the subsidy paid by the Government now for the care of its citizens?

    And then there is the question of whether even the 6% is adequate. The Government says, "Don't worry old chap. If that 6% is not enough, we will lend you the money and, what's more, we will charge you a modest interest on it. "That is the socialist government, a government that claims itself to be socialist we have in Singapore today - trying to make a profit out of the misfortunes of a man who falls ill and finds himself unable to pay his medical fees. I say shame upon the Government. Why can the Government not absorb, I ask, the total cost of medical care for Class C patients? It is not that we do not have the money.

    The Member for Rochore yesterday said this and he referred to the Payroll Tax, the Skills Development Fund. There are a number of other monies lying around. What about the surcharge or tax on PUB bills, the telephones. Well, if you still need the money, get it by direct taxation. But you have a duty to provide adequate medical care for those who are unable to pay for themselves. You cannot shelve that responsibility. At the moment, the highest income tax bracket in Singapore is 45%.

Column: 133

It was reduced by this Government from 55% to 45%. Well, why do you not put it up if you think we need a bit more money to take care of our ill?

    Let us see, Mr Speaker, Sir, how other countries in this region - I said "other countries" but I only want to refer to one country - take care of their patients who go into Class C or the equivalent of Class C wards. I am, of course, referring to our nearest neighbour, Malaysia. The outpatient clinics and dispensaries charge the user $1 per visit inclusive of medicine. Why do we have to charge, what is it, $5, $4? If Malaysia can afford to subsidize outpatient treatment for the poor at $1 per visit, are we much poorer than Malaysia?

    Then look at their third class hospital charges. They charge a third class patient $3 per day. Why do we, an affluent society, a society that is building up huge reserves for this rainy day which we think is going to come one of these days, why are we charging $10 for Class C beds? And not only that, we threaten our citizens with increasing it to $20 in the near future if this Medisave plan goes through, or I suppose even if it does not go through (not that it would not) I would not be able to stop this report being accepted.

    So there you have it, Sir. I want to know why is it that we cannot absorb this? Why is it not possible for us to reduce the cost of outpatient treatment for our citizens? Whoever drew up this report, have they looked at that? Have they given it any serious consideration? No, because they were told, "Just leave all that alone. We are charging them. Let them go on paying it. Your concern is to see how you can further reduce the Government's obligations in this respect." Mr Speaker, Sir, I could go on and on and on.

     An hon. Member: We know that.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: But I do not intend to do that because this report - and I say this very seriously, not in jest - is not worth the paper on which it is written. And it is a waste of time to debate this and to comment upon it as though it was a serious paper. The projections of demand that have been put up, we do not know on

Column: 134

what basis they have been put up, are all scanty. Do they not know of the Beveridge report that preceded the British Health Service, the study that went into it? This is a hotch potch report, not a report worthy of a government that prides itself of being very professional, very expert, in how it does its work.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, we have heard from the Minister, not only now but we have heard it several times, that we must not get into the position of the British Health Service or the health service in other countries where demand has outstripped supply because it is a free for all and therefore the service has degenerated and people are not getting enough adequate medical attention. This seems to be just emotional outbursts on the part of our leaders in an attempt to justify what they are doing. The Second Minister for Health quotes a report, what was it, "Health Crisis" or something. Well, there are other reports as well, Mr Second Minister for Health, and I do not know whether he has looked at these other reports, There is an analysis of medical care by Robert Maxwell. He is a leading medical analyst and he has compared 10 Western countries for the standard of health care that is provided in these countries. And what does he come up with? He finds that the United Kingdom spends least. They spend the least on health care among all these 10 countries. But they rank fourth in the standard of health that is provided. And what does he find about the United States? Because here I detect a tendency on the part of this Government to follow the United States to try and turn medical care over to the private sector as far as possible without Government controlling it. He finds that the United States spends the second highest amount compared with all these other nine countries. But where do they rank in the health rating? Mr Speaker, Sir, they rank at the bottom. They are the 10th in these 10 countries, spending the second highest. Why do we not study some other reports instead of reports that suit our case? Let us also look at other reports and see what is a fair, balanced report. There are the OECD reports. Let us look at all of them before we start condemning the British Health Service.

Column: 135



    It has been remarked - I am not saying this - but it has been remarked and written that the British Health Service is very cost effective. Why can't we do something like that? We can only do it if the Government 'retains control. Once the Government gives up control, then the costs will run away. If you let just the doctors, the private doctors, take over and they generate demand, then costs will go up. But if you, the Government, take control, you can keep costs down. Why do we not want to accept the responsibility? What is wrong with it? What is wrong with a pre-paid health service? Have you studied it seriously and then ruled it out? I would have expected in this National Health Plan some reference to the pre-paid health service what are the pros in favour of it; what are the arguments against it, and then a recommendation as to whether we should accept it or not. But we find nothing about it. It is treated as though it is not worthy of consideration. Why? We enter into (when I say "we" I mean the Government) enter into all sorts of businesses. Why don't we, the Government, enter into the business of taking care of our citizens? We do not have to be told this by an American, but was it last night or the night before, he was saying - he is here on a visit with nine others,[ think - he was saying that people are the most valuable resource in any country. We know that. We do not have any other resource. The only resource we have is our people. Why does not the Government enter into the business, seriously, of looking after them?

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I say that this report has gone completely off the track. It does not answer the question. And so I say to the two Ministers, "Take this report away, please. Look at it again, and tell us what your terms of reference are, and then present a report worthy of the Ministry and the Government.
